name: Willem-Paul Brinkman
content: Personal page of Willem-Paul Brinkman Zoeken Sluit zoek Willem-Paul Brinkman Biography In 2003 Willem-Paul Brinkman (1970) received his PhD degree in the area of human-computer interaction from Eindhoven University of Technology, The Netherlands. After that, he obtained his Postgraduate Certificate in Learning and Teaching in Higher Education from Brunel University of West London. Here, he worked for five years as a lecturer before moving to Delft University of Technology in 2007. He now works as an associate professor in the Interactive Intelligence group that works on understanding and engineering human-agent collaboration. Research Brinkman's primary research interests are human-computer interaction, human-centred artificial intelligence, behaviour change support systems, specifically as part of eHealth systems. He is fascinated by artificial social agents (conversational agents) that offer psychological assessment, support, therapy, or training. His ultimate objective is to establish (semi)autonomous eHealth systems with a digital psychologist that can assist individuals in achieving a broad set of behaviour change goals ranging from overcoming mental illness to lifestyle modification for coping with a chronic illness. He is, therefore, determined to build these systems and establish an empirically grounded understanding of them. For this, he works on several research grants that focus on these types of eHealth systems, such as home-based virtual reality therapy systems for patients with social anxiety or post-traumatic stress disorder, and artificial social agents for people with sleeping problems, depression, or nicotine addiction. Academic involvement Over the years, he has been involved in the organisation of several international conferences and workshops and acted as an associate or guest editor of several journals. He has co-authored over 50 journal papers and over 80 peer-reviewed conference and workshop publications. Brinkman is a senior member of the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM). Teaching Brinkman is the director of studies of the MSc Computer Science programme. In this role, he is responsible for the content, organisation and quality of the curricula.
